author: Dallas Morning News Editorial
title: John Wiley Price will finally get his day in court, and Dallas is ready for answers
text:

It feels like an eternity since FBI agents raided the home and office of one our city's most prominent public figures, Dallas County Commissioner John Wiley Price. 
But those raids, on June 27, 2011, set in play a years-long legal and political drama that cast Price at the center of what is among the biggest, most anticipated political corruption case in Dallas history. 
And now, with jury selection set to begin today, Price and his longtime executive assistant, Dapheny Fain, finally will get their day of reckoning. 
The stakes are obviously high for Price, Fain and another co-defendant, veteran political consultant Kathy Nealy, who will face trial later. But Dallas also has a lot riding on the outcome of this trial. The city's political corruption has been well established in cases involving other public officials over the years; just how deeply is it rooted? Hows and whys: Looking back and ahead on John Wiley Price's corruption case before his trial 
Price faces 11 counts of conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and income tax evasion. If convicted, he could face decades in prison and bring to a shameful end his reputation as "Our Man Downtown," a moniker he's carefully crafted for more than three decades while representing southern Dallas County. 
Price is accused of trading his political influence for nearly $1 million in money, cars and land. Fain and Nealy are accused of helping the commissioner secure and hide the bribes. All three have pleaded not guilty. 
A fourth defendant, Christian Lloyd Campbell, could buttress the government's case against Price. Campbell pleaded guilty in 2015 to helping funnel bribes to Price, with Nealy's help. 
At the heart of this trial is whether Price and others have violated the public's trust. It's a trial that will see some of the city's most prominent business and political titans — from H. Ross Perot Jr. to former Dallas Mayor Ron Kirk — take the stand, either as witnesses for the defendants, the government or both sides. Editorial: What Helena Tantillo's conviction says about the case against John Wiley Price 
We should be prepared to hold all the appropriate parties, be they public officials or private actors, accountable for any criminal or unethical behavior. If, as some political observers have suggested, the government's case against Price and his co-defendants signals that corruption is a systemic problem in Dallas, we should all brace ourselves. 
In many ways, this a pivotal moment — a trial that will shed light on the way Dallas does business. 
The city has waited years for answers, from the time Price's office was raided in 2011, when he was indicted in 2014 and through two re-election bids, with Price maintaining his innocence throughout. 
We are ready for the truth, whatever it is, to be known. It's time to let the evidence and facts speak for themselves. What's next? 
Key upcoming dates in the John Wiley Price public corruption trial: 
Today: Jury selection starts, and could run through Friday. Feb. 24 or 27: Testimony expected to begin, soon after a jury is seated. June 30: Prosecution and defense attorneys have agreed to wrap up the trial before this date. View Comments
